title: 42-Year-Old Hunter with Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have a high-pitched ringing in my ears that gets louder and lasts longer after I've been around loud noise. Speech often sounds muffled, and I have trouble hearing in groups or background noise.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual, with recent worsening of tinnitus duration.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; tinnitus is becoming more prolonged after exposure.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in groups and background noise.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Diagnosis and substantiation of the hearing problem.

history.present_illness: Patient reports high-pitched tinnitus that is exacerbated by noise exposure. He feels speech is muffled and struggles in noise.
history.noise_exposure_history: Significant recreational noise exposure: fond of deer and duck hunting; enjoys listening to rock music under earphones.
history.patient_goals: Determine cause of hearing difficulties and tinnitus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss characterized by a distinct acoustic trauma notch at 4000 Hz. The notch is deeper in the left ear. Hearing is within normal limits at 250-2000 Hz and recovers at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) are consistent with the pure-tone average of the better frequencies. Word recognition scores (SRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present but at elevated levels, consistent with cochlear recruitment.

tests.name: ABR
tests.key_findings: All waves prolonged; interpeak latencies normal; latency-intensity function steep. Results suggest cochlear pathology rather than retrocochlear.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: TEOAEs are absent bilaterally. Tone decay test at 4000 Hz showed minimal decay (negative for retrocochlear pathology).

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals a bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with a prominent 'notch' configuration at 4000 Hz, consistent with noise-induced cochlear damage. The loss is asymmetric, with the left ear showing a significantly greater threshold shift at 4000 Hz, which is typical for a right-handed shooter. Middle ear function is normal, and retrocochlear tests (ABR, Tone Decay) are negative. Speech recognition remains excellent in quiet.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss pattern is classic for noise exposure (acoustic trauma), specifically the 'notch' at 4000 Hz.
The left ear is worse likely due to the 'acoustic shadow' effect from shooting a rifle from your right shoulder.
It is critical to minimize future noise exposure to prevent the loss from spreading to speech frequencies.
Use hearing protection (such as special impact-noise plugs or foam plugs) whenever hunting or shooting.
Lower the volume when listening to music and prefer loudspeakers over earphones to reduce direct pressure on the ears.
We should re-evaluate your hearing in six months to monitor for any progression.
notes_for_actor: You are an outdoorsman who loves hunting and rock music.
You might be slightly defensive about your hobbies but are concerned about the ringing in your ears.
You have noticed the ringing takes longer to go away than it used to.
You have a family history of hearing loss (sisters) and might wonder if it's genetic, though the audiologist will explain yours is likely noise-related.
